parts: If B is closed in a topological space X, and f : X -> Y is a continuous function, and x is an element of X outside B, can we conclude that x is not a member of f^{-1}(closure(f(B)) ?

thoughts.content: I want to figure out if continuity and a closed subset imply that a point outside the subset maps outside the closure of the subset's image. But looking closely, I see a counterexample that disrupts this idea. If we take a constant function, a point can still map into the closure of the image even if it's outside the subset. So, no — it's not always true. But there's an interesting nuance about the preimage of the closure of the image containing the closure of the preimage.

But looking closely, I see a counterexample that disrupts this idea.
If we take a constant function, a point can still map into the closure of the image even if it's outside the subset.
So, no — it's not always true.
But there's an interesting nuance about the preimage of the closure of the image containing the closure of the preimage.

thoughts.content: I realized the preimage of a closure isn't always the closure of the preimage unless certain conditions hold, like when \( f \) is a closed map. Typically, the inverse image of a closure is at least the closure of the inverse image, but not necessarily equal. In the specific case, we can't conclusively say that \( x \notin f^{-1}(\text{cl} f(B)) \) without more conditions. For example, if \( f \) is a closed map, then it simplifies to \( x \notin f^{-1}(f(B)) \).

thoughts.content: If \( f \) is a closed map, \( x \) outside \( B \) could still map into \( f(B) \) if \( f \) is not injective. However, if \( f \) is injective and continuous, then \( x \notin B \) implies \( f(x) \notin f(B) \). But there’s a wrinkle: if \( f \) isn't a topological embedding, \( f(x) \) might be a limit point of \( f(B) \) even if it's not in the image.

However, if \( f \) is injective and continuous, then \( x \notin B \) implies \( f(x) \notin f(B) \).
But there’s a wrinkle: if \( f \) isn't a topological embedding, \( f(x) \) might be a limit point of \( f(B) \) even if it's not in the image.

thoughts.content: If \( f \) is continuous and injective but not a topological embedding, \( x \notin B \) can still have a sequence \( b_n \in B \) converging to \( x \), and their images will converge to \( f(x) \). But if \( B \) is closed, \( x \notin \text{cl}(B) \), so \( f(x) \) can't be a new limit point unless \( f \) is not injective.

But if \( B \) is closed, \( x \notin \text{cl}(B) \), so \( f(x) \) can't be a new limit point unless \( f \) is not injective.

thoughts.content: For an injective continuous map, even if \( f(x) \notin f(B) \), the closure could still include \( f(x) \) due to different closeness properties in the image. However, if \( f \) is a topological embedding (homeomorphism onto its image), then \( f(x) \) will not be in the closure of \( f(B) \).

thoughts.content: The statement about \( f(x) \notin f^{-1}(\text{cl } f(B)) \) does not hold in general. A counterexample is provided by constant maps—if \( f \) is constant, \( f(x) \in \text{cl } f(B) \) even if \( x \notin B \). For the conclusion to be valid, additional conditions are needed, such as \( f \) being a topological embedding.

parts:
No.

Take any nonempty proper closed \(B\subset X\), pick \(x\in X\setminus B\), let \(Y\) be any space with a point \(y_0\), and define the **constant** map \(f\equiv y_0\). Then
\[
f(B)=\{y_0\},\qquad \overline{f(B)}=\{y_0\},\qquad f(x)=y_0\in \overline{f(B)},
\]
so \(x\in f^{-1}(\overline{f(B)})\). Thus you cannot conclude \(x\notin f^{-1}(\overline{f(B)})\) in general.

When does the implication **hold**? If \(f\) is a **topological embedding** (a homeomorphism onto its image), then for any closed \(B\subset X\),
\[
\overline{f(B)}\cap f(X)=\overline_{\,f(X)}(f(B))=f(B),
\]
so \(f(x)\notin \overline{f(B)}\) whenever \(x\notin B\). (Sufficient conditions include: \(f\) continuous, injective, and closed onto its image.) 

In general you always have the inclusions
\[
B\subseteq f^{-1}(f(B))\subseteq f^{-1}(\overline{f(B)}),
\]
and these can be strict without additional hypotheses on \(f\).

Given that V is open, it seems that the closure of f(B) must be contained within the complement of V, meaning f(x) won’t be in the closure of f(B).

The condition also seems sufficient, as it ensures that f(x) belongs to an open set V disjoint from f(B), making f(x) not in the closure of f(B).

From this, we first conclude that f(B) is disjoint from V, which implies the closure of f(B) is still contained in Y \ V. parts:
Yes.

If \(V\subset Y\) is open with \(x\in f^{-1}(V)\) and \(f^{-1}(V)\subset X\setminus B\), then for every \(b\in B\) we have \(f(b)\notin V\). Hence
\[
f(B)\subset Y\setminus V \quad\Rightarrow\quad \overline{f(B)}\subset Y\setminus V,
\]
so \(f(x)\in V\) implies \(f(x)\notin \overline{f(B)}\). Equivalently,
\[
x\notin f^{-1}(\overline{f(B)}).
\]

In fact, your condition is **equivalent** to the conclusion:  
\(x\notin f^{-1}(\overline{f(B)})\) iff there exists an open \(V\ni f(x)\) with \(V\cap f(B)=\varnothing\) (equivalently \(f^{-1}(V)\cap B=\varnothing\)).  

(Notice the closedness of \(B\) wasn’t used once the \(V\) condition is assumed.)

Let us prove the converse. Suppose that there is a family of continuous maps f_\alpha X  :  X_\alpha -> X and that X is given the weak topology induced by these maps. Show that the collection { f_\alpha^{-1}(V) : V open in X_\alpha } is a basis of the topology on X if for any closed set B in X and any x not in B, there is some \alpha for which f_\alpha(x) \notin Closure_{X_\alpha}(f_\alpha(B))

thoughts.content: The user seems to want help with a math proof related to weak topologies. I'll clarify the statement: the weak topology on X is the coarsest topology making the family of maps \( f_\alpha : X \to X_\alpha \) continuous. The goal here is to prove that under a separation property, the collection \( \{ f_\alpha^{-1}(V) : V \text{ open in } X_\alpha \} \) forms a basis for the topology on X.

parts:
Yes—under that hypothesis the subbasic family becomes a basis.

Let \(\{f_\alpha:X\to X_\alpha\}\) and let
\[
\mathcal S=\{\,f_\alpha^{-1}(V):\ \alpha\ \text{and}\ V\subset X_\alpha\ \text{open}\,\},
\]
which is a subbasis for the weak (initial) topology on \(X\).

**Claim.** \(\mathcal S\) is a basis provided:

\((\star)\) For every closed \(B\subset X\) and every \(x\notin B\), there is \(\alpha\) with \(f_\alpha(x)\notin \overline{f_\alpha(B)}\) (closure in \(X_\alpha\)).

**Proof.** Take any open \(U\subset X\) and \(x\in U\). Put \(B:=X\setminus U\), which is closed and satisfies \(x\notin B\). By \((\star)\) choose \(\alpha\) with \(f_\alpha(x)\notin \overline{f_\alpha(B)}\). Then there exists an open \(V\subset X_\alpha\) such that
\[
f_\alpha(x)\in V\subset X_\alpha\setminus \overline{f_\alpha(B)}\subset X_\alpha\setminus f_\alpha(B).
\]
Hence \(f_\alpha^{-1}(V)\cap B=\varnothing\), i.e.
\[
x\in f_\alpha^{-1}(V)\subset X\setminus B=U.
\]
Thus for every open \(U\) and \(x\in U\) there is some \(f_\alpha^{-1}(V)\in\mathcal S\) with \(x\in f_\alpha^{-1}(V)\subset U\). By the standard “basis at a point” criterion, \(\mathcal S\) is a basis. ∎

**Remark (product/diagonal view).** Let \(\Delta:X\to \prod_\alpha X_\alpha\) be the diagonal \(x\mapsto (f_\alpha(x))\). Condition \((\star)\) is equivalent to: for every closed \(B\subset X\) and \(x\notin B\), \(\Delta(x)\notin \overline{\Delta(B)}\) in the product—so \(\Delta\) is a topological embedding. Then the basic cylinder neighborhoods in the product pull back to sets of the form \(f_\alpha^{-1}(V)\); hence they form a basis on \(X\).
